About the symbolic/DSL ecosystem  (modeling toolkit, soss etc) and where gen can fit in (genify vs MTK tracing, GFI and sampling for MTK problems etc)

messages.text: Hi everyone, I’m not sure if this is the correct place to ask questions. But I’m wondering why Gen doesn’t have a built-in NUTS sampler similar to those provided by Turing or Pyro.

messages.text: does gen have anything for continuous bayesian learning <https://discourse.julialang.org/t/recursive-bayes/55036/2>

attachments.title: Recursive Bayes
attachments.text: It’s funny, this is such a standard use of Bayesian analysis, but most PPLs don’t have much support for it. It’s usually better to do inference for as much data as you have at a time, because the posterior is represented as a function of the data. There are two main exceptions to this: If you make strong assumptions about the data, e.g. for a Kalman filter you assume normality. If you make very few assumptions, and do things very empirically. Then you end up with a particle filter. One big fo...

elements.text: does gen have anything for continuous bayesian learning

messages.text:
<@UDGT4PM41> Yes, Gen supports (many variants of) particle filtering.

There’s a tutorial example here: <https://www.gen.dev/tutorials/particle-filtering-in-gen/Particle%20Filtering%20in%20Gen>

A particularly compelling example of ‘continuous Bayesian learning’ in Gen, I think, is <@U01898ZDMK3>’s paper, from NeurIPS 2020: <https://arxiv.org/abs/2006.07532>. As the model observes an agent acting in an environment, it continuously updates its beliefs about the agent’s goals. The code is available at <https://github.com/ztangent/Plinf.jl>

Another cool example can be found in Marco’s thesis, Chapter 6.1: <https://www.mct.dev/assets/mct-thesis.pdf>

For more advanced use cases, there’s a package specifically for advanced SMC in Gen: <https://github.com/probcomp/GenParticleFilters.jl>

You might also find Marco’s 2018 PLDI paper on incremental inference interesting (this sort of SMC is now supported by Gen): <https://dl.acm.org/doi/10.1145/3296979.3192399>

attachments.title: Online Bayesian Goal Inference for Boundedly-Rational Planning Agents
attachments.text: People routinely infer the goals of others by observing their actions over time. Remarkably, we can do so even when those actions lead to failure, enabling us to assist others when we detect that...
attachments.fallback: arXiv.org: Online Bayesian Goal Inference for Boundedly-Rational Planning Agents
